name: OpenStax Microbiology Textbook - Chapter 17
description: Multiple-choice questions from the 'Multiple Choice' section of Chapter 17 of the OpenStax Microbiology textbook.
subject: Microbiology

questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: Which of the following best describes the innate nonspecific immune system?
options: a targeted and highly specific response to a single pathogen or molecule
a generalized and nonspecific set of defenses against a class or group of pathogens
a set of barrier mechanisms that adapts to specific pathogens after repeated exposure
the production of antibody molecules against pathogens
questions.explanation: The innate nonspecific immune system is a generalized and nonspecific set of defenses against a class or group of pathogens.

questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: Which of the following constantly sheds dead cells along with any microbes that may be attached to those cells?
questions.explanation: The epidermis constantly sheds dead cells, which helps to remove microbes from the surface of the skin.

questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: Which of the following uses a particularly dense suite of tight junctions to prevent microbes from entering the underlying tissue?
questions.explanation: The blood-brain barrier has very tight junctions between cells to prevent microbes from entering the central nervous system.

questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: Which of the following serve as chemical signals between cells and stimulate a wide range of nonspecific defenses?
questions.explanation: Cytokines are signaling molecules that play a crucial role in coordinating the immune response.

questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: Bacteriocins and defensins are types of which of the following?
questions.explanation: Bacteriocins and defensins are examples of antimicrobial peptides, which are small proteins that have broad-spectrum antimicrobial activity.

questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: Which of the following chemical mediators is secreted onto the surface of the skin?
questions.explanation: Sebum is an oily substance secreted by sebaceous glands onto the skin surface, where it helps to inhibit the growth of microbes.

questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: Identify the complement activation pathway that is triggered by the binding of an acute-phase protein to a pathogen.
questions.explanation: The lectin pathway of complement activation is triggered by the binding of mannose-binding lectin, an acute-phase protein, to carbohydrates on the surface of a pathogen.

questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: Histamine, leukotrienes, prostaglandins, and bradykinin are examples of which of the following?
options: chemical mediators primarily found in the digestive system
antimicrobial peptides found on the skin
questions.explanation: Histamine, leukotrienes, prostaglandins, and bradykinin are all chemical mediators that promote inflammation.

questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: White blood cells are also referred to as which of the following?
questions.explanation: White blood cells are also known as leukocytes.

questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: Hematopoiesis occurs in which of the following?
questions.explanation: Hematopoiesis, the process of blood cell formation, occurs in the bone marrow.

questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: Granulocytes are which type of cell?
questions.explanation: Granulocytes are a type of leukocyte (white blood cell).

questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: PAMPs would be found on the surface of which of the following?
questions.explanation: Pathogen-associated molecular patterns (PAMPs) are found on the surface of pathogens.

questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: ________ on phagocytes bind to PAMPs on bacteria, which triggers the uptake and destruction of the bacterial pathogens?
questions.explanation: Pattern recognition receptors (PRRs) on phagocytes bind to PAMPs on bacteria.

questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: Which of the following best characterizes the mode of pathogen recognition for opsonin-dependent phagocytosis?
options: Opsonins produced by a pathogen attract phagocytes through chemotaxis.
A PAMP on the pathogen’s surface is recognized by a phagocyte’s toll-like receptors.
A pathogen is first coated with a molecule such as a complement protein, which allows it to be recognized by phagocytes.
A pathogen is coated with a molecule such as a complement protein that immediately lyses the cell.
questions.explanation: In opsonin-dependent phagocytosis, a pathogen is first coated with opsonins, such as complement proteins, which allows it to be recognized and phagocytosed by phagocytes.

questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: Which refers to swelling as a result of inflammation?
questions.explanation: Edema is the medical term for swelling caused by excess fluid trapped in the body's tissues.

questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: Which type of inflammation occurs at the site of an injury or infection?
questions.explanation: Acute inflammation is the initial, rapid response to an injury or infection.
